On Nov 8, 2006, at 12:19 PM, spdomin wrote:

> Greetings,
>
> Could =
a developer on the Cantera project please change the  
> speciesData() meth=
od from:
>
> const XML_Node* speciesData() {
>   if (m_speciesData) {
>    =
  return m_speciesData;
>   }
>   else {
>      throw CanteraError("ThermoP=
hase::speciesData","m_speciesData  
> is NULL");
>      return 0;
>   }
> }=

>
> to:
>
> const XML_Node* speciesData() {
>    if (!m_speciesData) {
>  =
    throw  CanteraError("ThermoPhase::speciesData","m_speciesData  
> is NU=
LL");
>    }
>    return m_speciesData;
> }
>
> This method appears in the =
ThermoPhase.h header. The current  
> implementation provides a warning on =
a number of platforms that the  
> return statement is unreachable.
>
> Wit=
h best wishes,
>
> Stefan
>

cal_12@...> wrote:

>> Hi Thomas,
>>
>> You need to get to the folde=
r where the Cantera data files are  
>> stored.  Most likely this is
>>
>> =
C:\Program Files\Common Files\Cantera\Data
>>
>> though there should be a s=
hortcut to 'data' from inside your main  
>> Cantera folder, no matter wher=
e the data is stored.
>>
>> Find and open the file 'gri30.cti' I'd recommen=
d saving a copy of  
>> the original under a new name before making any cha=
nges, but any  
>> changes you make (and save) to this file should be refle=
cted in  
>> your simulations (make sure you select 'save as type: All File=
s',  
>> and put the '.cti' ending on it, or else your computer will  
>> p=
robably try to save it as a .txt file).
>>
>> I only use Cantera in Matlab,=
 and so maybe this isn't the case for  
>> Python, but I'm pretty sure it w=
ill solve your problem.
>>
>> Best of luck,
>> Steven
